awd_titl_txt: REU Site: The Mathematical Sciences Research Institute Undergraduate Program (MSRI-UP)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mathematical Sciences Research Institute Undergraduate Program (MSRI-UP) is more than a traditional REU program. MSRI-UP identifies talented undergraduates - particularly among racial and ethnic groups underrepresented in mathematics - who display great potential and motivation despite often having had limited opportunities and expertise. It then offers them the research experience, the training and resources, and the long-term mentorship and support necessary to pursue a graduate degree and a career in the mathematical sciences. The program provides: (1) an intense six-week summer research experience, (2) colloquia and professional development workshops, (3) the opportunity to present at national conferences, (4) an introduction to a wide community of peers and mentors; and (5) long-term follow-up and mentorship. Through its unique partnership with the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute, MSRI-UP offers its students access to excellent research facilities, a dynamic scientific atmosphere, constant interaction with internationally recognized mathematicians at all stages of their careers, and a six-week residence at  one of the country's top mathematics institutions.

MSRI-UP contributes significantly to increasing the number of graduate degrees in mathematics earned by U.S. students, and by members of underserved communities in particular. In the first 10 years of activity, 57 research projects have been conducted by 169 students, 85% from underrepresented groups and 46% women. Of the MSRI-UP alumni who have already graduated from college, 79% went on to graduate programs, almost all of them in the mathematical sciences. This is tremendously significant for a program that targets students with no previous research experience, who may not have seriously considered graduate programs due to lack of access, information, or encouragement. The five Lead Directors have substantial experience creating a rigorous and supportive research environment that emphasizes collaboration and communication, and ensures the active participation and success of every student. Each year, the mathematical activities are directed by a different Research Director who is an established researcher and mentor; this ensures that MSRI-UP engages the diversity of many different fields of mathematics. The structure of the program ensures a constant influx of new perspectives from a rotating set of mentors, and establishes a natural cycle for the training of future leaders in the mathematics community.

por.por_cntn:
The Mathematical Sciences Research Institute Undergraduate Program (MSRI-UP) is a comprehensive program for undergraduates that aims to increase the number of graduate degrees earned by U.S. citizens and permanent residents by cultivating the abundant and often overlooked mathematical ability of students from the U.S. Black, Hispanic/Latino, Native Pacific Islander, and Native American communities.

The primary objective of the MSRI-UP is to identify talented students who are interested in mathematics, especially those from underrepresented groups, and make available to them meaningful research opportunities, the necessary skills and knowledge to participate in successful collaborations, and a community of academic peers and mentors who can advise, encourage, and support them through a successful graduate program.

The program provides: (1) an intense six-week summer research experience, (2) colloquia and professional development workshops, (3) the opportunity to present at national conferences, (4) the introduction to a wide community of peers and mentors; and (5) long-term follow-up and mentorship.  MSRI-UP is run by a team of five program directors with support from the staff of MSRI.  Each year, one of the co-directors took the role of lead director with the specific task of managing the activities of the year?s cohort of students, as well as continuing and maintaining the relationships and connections with the students over the long term.

Each year, MSRI-UP ran with a different research theme and the mathematical activities were directed by a research leader who is an established mentor and an expert in the relevant area of mathematics. Each year, the research leaders were also supported by one post-doctoral scholar and two graduate student assistants. The research themes from 2017 until 2021 were, respectively: Solving Systems of Polynomial Equations, The Mathematics of Data Science, Combinatorics and Discrete Mathematics, Branched Covers of Curves, and Parking Functions: Choose your own adventure.

During each six-week residential program in Berkeley, California, career development activities included four to five colloquia from professional mathematicians; crash courses on using mathematical software, writing technical reports, and creating poster presentations; panels and workshops on graduate school preparation and careers in mathematics; as well as discussions about the experience of underrepresented students in mathematics graduate school. MSRI-UP Ph.D.-holding alumni were especially sought as visitors.

Due to COVID-19, the 2020 and 2021 MSRI-UP activities occurred in a virtual format. MSRI provided students with iPads and software licenses to use the Zoom video-conferencing platform, as well as other online collaborative tools and mathematical applications. While it was not possible to replicate the in-person experience online, the MSRI-UP staff worked assiduously to generate similar benefits, such as morning gatherings dedicated to hanging out, talking about life, playing games, and bonding. The professional development activities, workshops, and panel discussions mentioned above were also part of the virtual programming.

In the 2017 ? 2021 MSRI-UP programs, 89 students from 62 universities worked in teams to complete 30 research projects. Of the students, 46% identified themselves as women and 93% identified themselves as being from racial/ethnic groups underrepresented in mathematics (46% Latinx, 36% Black, 2% Native American, 2% Pacific Islander, and 6% multi-racial). Of the 251 students who have so-far completed their undergraduate degrees since MSRI-UP began, 200 continued on to graduate programs with 149 of them eventually continuing to a Ph.D. program. So far, 50 students have earned a Ph.D. and 97 students have earned a master?s degree with many more still underway.

Several of the students? research projects conducted during this grant period have been submitted to peer-reviewed journals with four papers having already been published. Students gave oral presentations during the summer research program and each team wrote final research reports and also created posters of their work. The MSRI-UP student teams presented their work at national conferences including Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science, National Association of Mathematicians, Gulf Coast Undergraduate Research Symposium, SIAM Conference on Computational Science and Engineering, and the Joint Mathematics Meetings, among others.
